application.desc: GROBID - A machine learning software for extracting information from scholarly documents

div.p: This paper is concerned with the distributed consensus tracking problem of uncertain multiagent systems with directed communication topology and a single high-dimensional leader. Compared with existing related works, the dynamics of each follower in the present framework are subject to unmodeled dynamics and unknown external disturbances, which is more practical in various applications. Furthermore, the dimensions of leader's dynamics may be different with those of the followers' dynamics. Under the mild assumption that each follower can directly or indirectly sense the output information of the leader, a distributed robust adaptive neural network controller together with a local observer are designed to each follower to ensure that the states of each follower ultimately synchronize to the leader's output with bounded residual errors under a fixed topology. By appropriately constructing some multiple Lyapunov functions, the derived results are further extended to consensus tracking with switching directed communication topologies. The effectiveness of the analytical results is demonstrated via numerical simulations.

in recent studies [1]- [4]. Consensus, as one of the most important collective behaviors in multiagent systems, has received particular attention within this context [5]- [7]. It indeed is a familiar phenomenon seen in our daily life, typical examples in point include fireflies flashing in unison, heading consensus of birds, phase synchrony of brain dynamics, among many others.

Many efforts have been made to investigate how to achieve consensus in multiagent systems under dynamically changing communication environments. As a result, many profound results have been obtained and reported in the literature (see survey paper [8] and some references therein). By using tools from algebraic graph theory and control theory, it was shown in [7] that consensus for networks of agents with single-integrator dynamics can be achieved if and only if the time-varying directed network topology jointly has a spanning tree as the network evolves on time. Consensus of second-order multiagent systems with jointly-connected topologies was investigated in [9] by using the Lyapunovbased analysis approach. Recently, robust consensus control for multiagent systems [10], consensus with adaptive coupling [11], [12], consensus in multiagent systems with state constraints [13], and consensus in general linear multiagent systems [14]- [16] have been also investigated by researchers from various scientific communities. According to the presence or absence of a leader in the considered multiagent systems, consensus problems can be divided into two categories: 1) leaderless consensus and 2) consensus tracking problems. Leaderless consensus means that the states of all dynamic agents could achieve a prior unknown agreement. In contrast, the states of the multiple agents in the context of consensus tracking framework will converge to a predesigned state trajectory. By constructing a local controller incorporated with a neighbor-based state estimation rule, consensus tracking for multiagent systems with an active leader and variable topology for first-and second-order followers were investigated in [17] and [18], respectively. Robustness performance indexes of consensus tracking in firstand second-order multiagent systems were, respectively, analyzed in [19] and [20] by using tools from frequency-domain approach. By using pinning control approach, consensus tracking for a class of multiagent systems with nonlinear coupling was considered in [21]. Furthermore, consensus tracking problem for multiagent systems with Lipschitztype nonlinear dynamics was studied in [22]- [24]. These studies have advanced our knowledge on how to achieve 2168-2267 c 2016 IEEE. Personal use is permitted, but republication/redistribution requires IEEE permission.
See http://www.ieee.org/publications_standards/publications/rights/index.html for more information.

consensus tracking in a group of multiple agents with a single leader. However, one common assumption in most existing literature on consensus tracking problem of multiagent systems is that the leader and the followers have identical dynamic models. Such an assumption offers us ability to directly analyze the evolution of consensus tracking errors for the closedloop multiagent systems. Comparatively speaking, consensus tracking problem for multiagent systems where the dynamics of leader and those of the followers described by heterogeneous models has not received substantial attention. Note that, in some practical cases, dynamics of the leader are more complex than those of the followers and only some partial information on the leader can be sensed by a fraction of team members. Two examples are distributed sensor networks with a complex target system [25] and the tractor-trailer systems with a fire truck and several trailers [26]. A general framework for analyzing the consensus tracking problem of multiagent systems with a high-dimensional leader has been suggested in [27]. Obviously, a deep research on consensus tracking of multiagent systems with a high-dimensional leader is a critical step to study the collective behaviors of heterogeneous multiagent systems, thus benefiting engineers to implement communication protocols for tracking a target with strong maneuverability by using simple yet low-cost agents. However, in most of the aforementioned works, the priori knowledge concerning the exact model of agent dynamics is needed for protocol design. But oftentimes, there may exist unmodeled uncertainties and unknown external disturbances in networked agents [28]. Recently, neuro-adaptive consensus tracking protocols have been developed for multiagent systems with unmodeled dynamics and unknown external disturbances under different scenarios [29]- [33]. Leaderless consensus and consensus tracking problems for first-order multiagent systems with nonlinear dynamics and unknown disturbances were, respectively, studied in [29] and [30] by designing some new neuro-adaptive control protocols. By appropriately introducing some sliding model errors, neuro-adaptive consensus tracking problems for second-order and higher-order nonlinear multiagent systems in the presence of unknown external disturbances were investigated, respectively, in [31] and [32]. Then, by using a combined tool from neuro-adaptive design approach and output feedback theory, consensus tracking for general nonlinear multiagent systems with external disturbances was addressed in [33].

This paper further investigates the consensus tracking problem for multiagent systems with a high-dimensional leader and switching directed topologies, with particular attention to the case that the dynamics of leader describe by a nonlinear system and the evolutions of the followers are described by linear systems but subject to unmodeled dynamics as well as unknown external disturbances. Hence, the existing analytical methods for solving the consensus tracking problem of multiagent systems with only nominal dynamics are inapplicable for this case. To solve such a consensus tracking problem, one need to first identify the unknown agent dynamics and then try best to compensate them in the closed-loop multiagent systems. Another challenge in solving such a problem is that the measurable output of high-dimensional leader is available only to a subset of followers. Motivated by the desire to compensate for the unmodeled dynamics and the work in [29]- [33], a new kind of consensus tracking protocols consisting of a neuro-adaptive local controller and a distributed observer is designed in the present manuscript. Specifically, the neuro-adaptive distributed observer is designed based only on the relative information of neighboring agents, taking the role of reconstruct the unmeasurable state information of the leader; the local controller is designed to make the states of each follower track some carefully selected observers' states. It will be proven that when the fixed communication topology contains a directed spanning tree rooted at the leader and the control parameters of the protocol are appropriately designed, the states of followers can track the output of the leader with bounded residual errors. The results are then extended to the case with periodic switching directed topology where each possible topology contains a directed spanning tree rooted at the leader. Finally, some numerical simulations are performed to verify the effectiveness of the theoretical results.

The rest of this paper is organized as follows. Some preliminaries and the problem formulation are given in Section II. The main theoretical results are then provided in Section III. In Section IV, two numerical examples are presented. The conclusions are finally drawn in Section V.

Throughout this paper, let R be the set of real numbers and R n×p be the set of n × p real matrices, respectively. N represents the set of positive natural numbers. Let I n and O n be, respectively, the n × n identity and zero matrices, and 1 n (0 n ) be the n-dimensional column vector with all entries being one (zero). Suppose that all the eigenvalues of A are real, λ min (A) denotes its smallest eigenvalue. The matrix inequality A > B means that both A and B are symmetric real matrices and A -B is positive-definite. Notation diag(A 1 , A 2 , . . . , A n ) represents a block-diagonal matrix with A i as its ith diagonal element, i = 1, 2, . . . , n. The Kronecker product is represented by ⊗. Symbols • , • F , and • 2 represent, respectively, the Euclidian norm of a vector, the Frobenius norm, and the spectral norm of a matrix. For a matrix A ∈ R m×n , denote its trace by tr(A). Matrices, if not explicitly stated, are assumed to have compatible dimensions.

div.head: II. PRELIMINARIES AND PROBLEM FORMULATION
div.p: Some preliminaries on algebraic graph theory, basic lemmas on matrix analysis, and the problem formulation are provided in this section.

div.head: A. Preliminaries
div.p: Let G(V, E, A) be a digraph with the set of vertices V = {1, 2, . . . , N + 1}, the set of directed edges E ⊆ {(i, j), i, j ∈ V}, and a weighted adjacency matrix A = [a ij ] (N+1)×(N+1) with non-negative elements a ij . The directed edge (i, j) in graph G(V, E, A) is associated with two ordered vertices i and j which are, respectively, called the parent and child vertices. Denote G(V, E, A) by G if there is no confusion will arise. A path on G from vertex i 1 to vertex i s is a sequence of ordered edges of the form (i k , i k+1 ), k = 1, 2, . . . , s -1. Note that only simple graph is considered here, i.e., multiple edges and self-loops are forbidden in G. A digraph is said to have or contain a directed spanning tree if there exists a node called root such that there exists a directed path from this node to each other node. The adjacency matrix A = [a ij ] (N+1)×(N+1) of a digraph G is defined by a ii = 0 for i = 1, 2, . . . , N + 1, and a ij > 0 for ( j, i) ∈ E but 0 otherwise. The Laplacian matrix L = [l ij ] (N+1)×(N+1) is defined as l ij = -a ij , i = j, and l ii = N+1 k=1 a ik for i = 1, 2, . . . , N + 1. Lemma 1 [6]: The Laplacian matrix L of digraph G has a simple zero eigenvalue and all the other eigenvalues have positive real parts if and only if G has a directed spanning tree.
Before moving on, some basic lemmas on matrix theory are provided as follows.
Lemma 2 [34]: For any given x, y ∈ R n , and matrices P > 0, D and S of appropriate dimensions, one has 2x T DSy ≤ x T DPD T x + y T S T P -1 Sy.

Suppose that M ∈ R n×n is a positive definite matrix and H ∈ R n×n is symmetric, one then has that matrix pencil H, M n×n is normal [34]. By using the norm matrix pencil theory, one knows that all the eigenvalues of matrix M -1 H are real for any given symmetric matrix H ∈ R n×n and positive definite matrix M ∈ R n×n [34]. Based on the above analysis, one can establish the following lemma.
Lemma 3: Suppose that M ∈ R n×n is a positive definite matrix and H ∈ R n×n is symmetric. Then, for any vector x ∈ R n , the following inequality holds:
div.formula: λ min M -1 H x T Mx ≤ x T Hx ≤ λ max M -1 H x T Mx.

div.head: B. Problem Formulation
div.p: Consider a multiagent system consisting of N + 1 agents where agent N + 1 is designated as the leader and the rest are designated as the followers. The dynamics of the leader are described as
div.formula: θ(t) = Aθ(t) + g(θ (t), t) y(t) = Cθ(t).
div.p: The vector θ(t) ∈ R nm indicates the state of the leader, n and m are two positive natural numbers, A ∈ R nm×nm represents the system matrix, nonlinear function g(θ (t), t) : R nm × [0, +∞) → R nm is a continuously differentiable vector-valued function satisfying the global Lipschitz condition
for some γ ≥ 0. Suppose that the state of the leader can be partitioned as
div.formula: θ(t) = (θ 1 (t) T , θ 2 (t) T , . . . , θ n (t) T ) T with θ i (t) ∈ R m , i = 1, 2, . . . , n.
div.p: Then, one may partition A = [â ij ] nm×nm into the following form:
where Âij ∈ R m×m , i, j = 1, 2, . . . , n. Furthermore, the nonlinear function g(θ (t), t) is assumed to be partitioned as g(θ (t
div.formula: ), t) = (g 1 (θ 1 (t), t) T , g 2 (θ 2 (t), t) T , . . . , g n (θ n (t), t) T ) T where g i (θ i (t), t) : R m × [0, +∞) → R m is a continuously differentiable vector-valued function.
div.p: The vector y(t) ∈ R m is the output information of the leader which is assumed to be available to a subset of followers, output matrix C ∈ R m×nm .
For the convenience of analysis, it is assumed that
div.formula: C = (O m , O m , . . . , O m , I m ) ∈ R m×nm and ( C, A) is detectable.
div.p: Note that in many practical multiagent systems, the leader plays the role of a command generator providing a reference state for the followers to track. Thus, in this paper, it is assumed that the evolution of the leader will not be affected by those of any followers.
The dynamics of ith (1 ≤ i ≤ N) follower are given as
div.formula: x i (t) = Ax i (t) + f i (x i (t)) + ω i (t) + u i (t)(4)
div.p: where
div.formula: x i (t) = (x i1 (t), x i2 (t), . . . , x im (t)) T ∈ R m is the state vector, smooth functions f i (x i (t)) : R m → R m describe the unknown unmodeled dynamics, ω i (t) ∈ R m are the unknown disturbances, A ∈ R m×m is a known matrix.
div.p: For practicability, it is assumed that the initial condition θ(0) is unknown to each follower and only the output information y(t) of the leader can be measured by some designed followers. The control goal in this paper is to design some consensus tracking protocols u i (t), i = 1, 2, . . . , N, under which the states of the followers ultimately track the output of the single leader [given by (1)] with bounded residual errors.

The communication topology among the N+1 agents is represented by a digraph G(V, E, A), where V = {1, 2, . . . , N+1} represents the set of agents, E is the set of edges (i.e., communication channels) and A = [a ij ] (N+1)×(N+1) is the adjacency matrix. Since the leader has no neighbors, one has that a (N+1)j = 0, for all j = 1, 2, . . . , N. Thus, the Laplacian matrix L of topology G can be partitioned as
div.formula: L = L a 0 T N 0(5)
div.p: where
div.formula: L ∈ R N×N and a = (a 1(N+1) , a 2(N+1) , . . . , a N(N+1) ) T ∈ R N .
div.p: Here, a i(N+1) > 0 if and only if follower i can directly sense the output information of the leader, i = 1, 2, . . . , N. In this paper, the controllers u i (t), (1 ≤ i ≤ N), are designed as follows:
div.formula: u i (t) = u ct i (t) + u ft i (t) (6)
div.p: where u ct i (t) and u ft i (t) are, respectively, the observer-based compensation term and the local feedback term given as
div.formula: u ct i (t) = Ãx i (t)+g n z n i (t), t + n-1 j=1 Ânj z j i (t)-αF n η i (t) u ft i (t) = -β x i (t) -z n i (t) -Ŵi (t) T ϕ i (x i (t)) (7) of which Ã = Ânn -A, z j i (t) ∈ R m , i = 1, 2, . . . , N, j = 1, 2, . . . , n, z i (t) = (z 1 i (t) T , z 2 i (t) T , . . . , z n i (t) T ) T ∈ R nm
div.p: is the state of the estimator embedded at follower i such that
div.formula: żk i (t) = g k z k i (t), t + n j=1 Âkj z j i (t) -αF k η i (t), k = 1, 2, . . . , n(8)
div.p: where Âkj , k = 1, 2, . . . , n, j = 1, 2, . . . , n, are given in (3), α and β are positive scalars to be selected, and
div.formula: η i (t) = N j=1 a ij z n j (t) -z n i (t) + a i(N+1) y(t) -z n i (t)(9)
div.p: the feedback gain matrix
div.formula: F = (F T 1 , F T 2 , . . . , F T n )
div.p: T and the coefficient matrices Ŵi (t), i = 1, 2, . . . , N, will be designed later.

Since the dimensions of the leader's and the followers' dynamics are different, the multiagent system under consideration is indeed heterogeneous. Further, only some partial information of the leader is available for some followers. To make the states of each follower ultimately synchronize to the output of the leader with bounded residual errors, the controller u i (t) associated with an estimator (8) are constructed. As it will be seen that the estimator z i (t), for each i = 1, 2, . . . , N, can be regarded as a full-order observer of the high-dimensional leader. Typically, only the relative local information between agents and the neighbors can be used for controller design within the context of multiagent system theory. In the present design framework, the vector η i (t) defined in (9) represents the relative local information available to follower i (1 ≤ i ≤ N). However, to compensate the effect of unmeasurable states of high-dimensional leader on consensus tracking, the compensation term u ct i (t) defined in ( 7) is utilized. Furthermore, the local feedback term u ft i (t) is designed to achieve consensus tracking and reduce the effect of followers' unknown unmodeled dynamics on consensus tracking. It is also worth pointing out that another possible way to solve such a distributed consensus tracking problem with partial information of the leader is the distributed output regulation-based approach [35].
By noticing that the nonlinear functions f i (x i (t)), i = 1, 2, . . . , N, in (4) are smooth, it can be thus obtained from Stone-Weierstrass approximation theorem [36]
div.formula: that f i (x i (t)) can be approximated on a compact set ⊂ R m by f i (x i (t)) = W T i ϕ i (x i (t)) + i , ∀x i (t) ∈(10)
div.p: where
div.formula: ϕ i (•) : R m → R s is a known basis function, W i ∈ R s×m is the ideal neural network (NN) weight matrix, i ∈ R m is the NN approximation error. Suppose that max x i (t)∈ ϕ i (x i (t)) is finite, i.e.
div.p: , there exists a positive scalar ϕ iM > 0 such that (11) for each i = 1, 2, . . . , N. Furthermore, one may let
div.formula: max x i (t)∈ ϕ i (x i (t)) ≤ ϕ iM
W iM = W i F as W i in (10) is a constant matrix. Take ϕ(x(t)) = (ϕ 1 (x 1 (t)) T , ϕ 2 (x 2 (t)) T , . . . , ϕ N (x N (t)) T ) T , W = diag(W 1 , W 2 , . . . , W N ) and = ( T 1 , T 2 , .
div.p: . . , T N ) T , one then gets that there exist positive scalars ϕ M , W M , and M such that ϕ(x(t)) ≤ ϕ M , W F ≤ W M , and ≤ M . As pointed out in [37], a variety of basis sets can be selected, such as sigmoids, Gaussians, and hyperbolic tangents, to name just a few. The ideal approximating weight matrix W i in ( 10) is assumed to be unknown, i.e., W i cannot be directly used for controller design. To compensate for unknown nonlinearities effectively, a new kind of NN-based estimators is designed to each follower to approximate the nonlinearities online. Define the local approximation of
div.formula: f i (x i (t)) as fi (x i (t)) = Ŵi (t) T ϕ i (x i (t)) (12
div.p: where Ŵi (t) ∈ R s×m is the current estimate of the ideal weights for follower i, i = 1, 2, . . . , N. For notational brevity, let
Before moving on, the following assumptions are made. Assumption 1: Digraph G contains a directed spanning tree with node N + 1 as the root.

Assumption 2: There exists a positive scalar ω M such that the external disturbances ω i (t) in (4) satisfy the following condition: ω(t) ≤ ω M , for all t ≥ 0, where ω(t) = (ω 1 (t) T , ω 2 (t) T , . . . , ω N (t) T ) T .
Assumption 3: The leader's trajectory is in a bounded region, e.g., θ(t) < θ M , for all t ≥ 0 and some constant θ M > 0.

Remark 1: Note that Assumption 1 is mild. For example, suppose that the subgraph describing the communication topology among the N followers is strongly connected, Assumption 1 will be satisfied when at least one follower can directly sense the output information of the leader. More generally, suppose that the directed graph describing the communication topology among followers has κ strongly connected components without any incoming link. Assumption 1 holds if there is a follower in each such component that can directly sense the output of the leader. In this case, the minimum number of followers should be informed by the leader to make Assumption 1 hold is κ. Note also that, for a given directed graph, it is possible to find all of its strongly connected components in linear time. Furthermore, Assumptions 2 and 3 are quite standard in the filed of NN-based distributed control of multiagent systems (see [31], [32]).
We are now in a position to formulate the consensus tracking problem considered in this paper.

Definition 1: The multiagent system consisting of the highdimensional leader (1) and the followers (4) equipped with the controller (6), is said to solve the consensus tracking problem with residual error > 0, if, lim t→∞ x i (t)y(t) ≤ , for all i = 1, 2, . . . , N.

It is worth noting that, despite many significant achievements have been made on achieving consensus tracking/pinning synchronization for homogeneous networking systems, we continue to lack tools to efficiently guarantee consensus tracking for multiagent systems with unknown dynamics and a high-dimensional leader. The main challenges are twofold: first, to obtain the consensus tracking error system, one needs to reconstruct the unmeasurable dynamics of high-dimensional leader by designing distributed observers; and second, the effects of unmodeled dynamics and unknown external disturbances on consensus tracking should be coped with online while only local relative information is available.

Remark 2: Note that one closely related topic to consensus tracking of multiagent systems is the pinning synchronization of complex dynamical networks where it is always assumed that the full state information of the target node (i.e., the leader) is available to some following nodes (see [38]- [41]). Two slight differences between consensus tracking of multiagent systems and pinning synchronization of complex networks are summarized below. First, complex networks are typically refer to the large-scale graphs with nontrivial topological features while multiagent systems may have trivial topological properties; furthermore, the inner linking matrices of complex networks are commonly assumed to be fixed while the feedback gain matrices in communication protocols of multiagent systems are generally designable.

div.head: III. MAIN RESULTS
div.p: In this section, the main results are provided and proved.

div.head: A. Neuro-Adaptive Consensus Tracking Control Over Fixed and Directed Multiagent Networks
div.p: In this subsection, NN-based adaptive consensus tracking control of multiagent systems with a fixed communication topology is addressed.

Under Assumption 1, it can be obtained from Lemma 1 that the matrix L in ( 5) is a nonsingular M-matrix [42]. Then, according to [42, Th. 2.3, p. 134], there exists a positive definite diagonal matrix = diag(ξ 1 , ξ 2 , . . . , ξ N ) such that L T + L > 0. As shown in [12], one such diagonal matrix can be specifically chosen as

For notational brevity, let λ 0 = λ min L+ -1 L T (17) of which = diag(ξ 1 , ξ 2 , . . . , ξ N ) and (ξ 1 , ξ 2 , . . . , ξ N ) T = ( L T ) -1 1 N .
div.p: Before moving forward, a multistep design procedure is given to select the control parameters of controller (6) and observer (8) under the fixed topology G.
Algorithm 1: Under Assumptions 1-3, and the condition that ( C, A) is detectable, the control parameters of controller (6) and observer (8) can be designed as follows.
1) Set α > 0 and c 0 > 0. Then, solve the following linear matrix inequality (LMI):
div.formula: A T P+P A-αλ 0 C T C+I nm + c 0 P γ P γ P -I nm < 0 (18)
div.p: to get a matrix P > 0, where λ 0 is defined in (17). Then, choose F = -P -1 C T . 2) Choose c 1 > 0, c 2 > 0, and β > (χ max + c 2 /2), where χ max represents the maximal real part of the eigenvalues of Ânn . Solve the following LMI:
div.formula: ÂT nn Q + Q Ânn -(2β -c 2 )Q < 0 (19

div.formula: Ẇi (t) = W i ϕ i (x i (t))δ i (t) T Q -c 1 Ŵi (t)(20)
div.p: where
Then, one can establish the following theorem which summarizes the main results of this subsection.

Theorem 1: Suppose that Assumptions 1-3 hold, LMIs ( 18) and ( 19) admit some feasible solutions. Then, the consensus tracking problem defined in Definition 1 for the multiagent system modeled by ( 1) and ( 4) can be solved by the neuro-adaptive protocol (6) associated with the observer (8) with control parameters designed by Algorithm 1. Specially, for each i = 1, 2, . . . , N

where c 0 > 0 is defined in Algorithm 1. By the fact that θ(t) ≤ θ M , it can be concluded from (26) that the trajectory z(t) for any given initial condition z(0) is uniformly bounded. Furthermore, it can be further obtained that

div.p: where ξ min = min i=1,2,...,N ξ i , λ min (P) represents the minimum eigenvalue of P. The above analysis indicates that z n i (t) will converge to y(t) with an exponential decay rate c 0 /2.
Construct the following Lyapunov function for the consensus tracking error system (16):

Remark 3: From the proof of Theorem 1, it can be seen that the states of all followers are uniformly bounded for an arbitrarily given initial condition. It is thus reasonable to assume that x i (t), i = 1, 2, . . . , N, are contained in a compact set ⊂ R m . Furthermore, it is also worth noting that the size of the compact set is not needed for the protocol design which can be set as large as needed in practice. Also, the positives scalars W M , M , ω M , and θ M , could be actually unknown since none of them is involved in the protocol design.

Remark 4: To solve the consensus tracking problem in multiagent system consisting of the leader (1) and the followers (4), each follower need to maintain a distributed observer (8) to estimate the states of the high-dimensional leader. The local feature of the observer (8), as reflected in fact that only some local information has been used for observer design, is much favorable in some practical applications. This indicates that it is unnecessary to employ a centralized estimator which having the ability to communicate with all followers for solving such a consensus tracking problem (stated in Definition 1).

Remark 5: The feasibility problems of LMIs ( 18) and ( 19) are analyzed as follows. The feasibility condition of LMI ( 18) is first provided. Since the positive scalars α and c 0 are free parameters in LMI (18), it can be obtained from the continuity theory that the feasibility of ( 18) is equivalent to the following feasible problem: there exist a positive scalar α and a positive definite matrix P such that the following algebraic Riccati inequality (ARI) holds:
div.formula: A T P+P A -α C T C + I nm + γ 2 P 2 < 0 (36
div.p: where γ is defined in (2). On the other hand, it can be obtained from Finsler's lemma [43] that there exist a positive scalar α and a matrix P > 0 such that ARI (36) holds if and only if there exist matrices F ∈ R nm×m and P > 0 such that
div.formula: A T P+P A -F C -C T F T + I nm + γ 2 P 2 < 0. (37
div.p: Without loss of any generality, let F = PS. Then, one gets that LMI ( 18) is feasible if and only if there exist a matrix S ∈ R nm×m and a P > 0, such that the following ARI holds:
div.formula: A -S C T P + P A -S C + I nm + γ 2 P 2 < 0. (38
div.p: By the bounded real lemma [44] in H ∞ control theory, one has ARI (38) holds if and only if there exists a matrix S ∈ R nm×m such that
div.formula: γ sI nm -A -S C -1 ∞ < 1(39)
div.p: that is
div.formula: sI nm -A -S C -1 ∞ < 1/γ . (40
div.p: This means that LMI (18) is feasible if and only if there exists a matrix S ∈ R nm×m such that (40) holds. It can also derived from the above analysis that ( C, A) detectable is a necessary but not sufficient condition for the feasibility of LMI (18). Next, the feasibility of LMI ( 19) is analyzed. According to fact that β > (χ max + c 2 /2) for some c 2 > 0 and χ max is the maximal real part of the eigenvalues of Ânn , one knows that LMI ( 19) is always feasible. Indeed, one feasible solution for LMI (19) is
div.formula: Q = I m .

div.head: B. Neuro-Adaptive Consensus Tracking Control Over Periodic Switching Multiagent Networks
div.p: Based on the analysis provided in the last subsection, neuroadaptive consensus tracking problem for multiagent system describing by ( 1) and ( 4) with periodic switching and directed communication topology is studied in this subsection.

Suppose that there exists an infinite sequence of uniformly bounded nonoverlapping time intervals [t k , t k+1 ), k ∈ N, with t 1 = 0, t k+1t k = h > 0, over which the communication topology is time-invariant. The time sequence t 1 , t 2 , . . . , is called the switching sequence, at which the communication topology switches. For expressional convenience, introduce a switching signal σ (t) : [0, +∞) → {1, . . . , q}. Then, let G σ (t) be the interaction graph of the considered multiagent system at time t. For the convenience of analysis, it is assumed that the node set of switching graph G σ (t) is fixed as V = {1, 2, . . . , N + 1}. The associated adjacency and Laplacian matrices are denoted by
div.formula: A σ (t) = [a σ (t) ij ] (N+1)×(N+1) and L σ (t) = [l σ (t) ij ] (N+1)×(N+1)
div.p: , respectively. Obviously, G σ (t) ∈ G for all t ≥ 0, where G = {G 1 , . . . , G q }, q > 1, denote the set of all possible directed topologies. Throughout this subsection, the derivatives of all signals at any switching instant are their right derivatives. Assumption 4: For each i ∈ {1, . . . , q}, digraph G i has a directed spanning tree with node N + 1 as the root.
Since the leader has no neighbors, the Laplacian matrix L σ (t) associated with the interaction graph G σ (t) can be partitioned as
div.formula: L σ (t) = L σ (t) a σ (t) 0 T N 0
div.p: where a σ (t) ∈ R N , L σ (t) ∈ R N×N , and t ≥ 0. Under Assumption 4, one has that there exist positive vectors
div.formula: ξ σ (t) = (( L σ (t) ) T ) -1 1 N such that σ (t) L σ (t) + L σ (t) T σ (t) > 0(41)
div.p: where
div.formula: σ (t) = diag(ξ σ (t) 1 , ξ σ (t) 2 , . . . , ξ σ (t) N ) and ξ σ (t) = (ξ σ (t) 1 , ξ σ (t) 2 , . . . , ξ σ (t)
div.p: N ) T . Based on the above analysis, one has that all the eigenvalues of L σ (t) +( σ (t) ) -1 ( L σ (t) ) T σ (t) are real and positive. For notational convenience, let λ0 = min i=1,2,...,q λi 0 (42) where λi 0 = λ min ( L i +( i ) -1 ( L i ) T i ) for i = 1, 2, . . . , q. The observer error system and the consensus tracking error system can be, respectively, obtained as
div.formula: ė(t) = I N ⊗ A + α L σ (t) ⊗ F C e(t) + g(e(t), t)(43)
δ(t) = I N ⊗ Ânn δ(t) -W(t) T ϕ(x(t)) -βδ(t) + + ω(t)(44)
div.p: where the notations are defined the same as those in the last section.
To proceed on, a multistep design procedure is given for selecting the control parameters of controller (6) and observer (8) under switching topology G σ (t) .
Algorithm 2: Under Assumptions 1, 2, and 4, and the condition that ( C, A) is detectable, the control parameters of controller (6) and observer (8) be designed as follows.
1) Set α > 0 and c0 > 0. Solve the following LMI:
div.formula: A T P+P A-α λ0 C T C+I nm + c0 P γ P γ P -I nm < 0 (45)
div.p: to get a matrix P > 0, where λ0 is defined in (42). Then, set F = -P -1 C T . 2) Set c1 > 0, c2 > 0, and β > (χ max + c2 /2), where χ max represents the maximal real part of the eigenvalues of Ânn . Solve the following LMI:
div.formula: ÂT nn Q + Q Ânn -(2β -c2 )Q < 0 (46) IEEE TRANSACTIONS ON CYBERNETICS
div.p: to get one solution Q > 0. Then, design the neuroadaptive tuning law as
div.formula: Ẇi (t) = W i ϕ i (x i (t))δ i (t) T Q -c1 Ŵi (t)(47)
div.p: where δ i (t) = x i (t)z n i (t), i = 1, 2, . . . , N. Then, one may get the following theorem which states the main results of this subsection.

Theorem 2: Suppose that Assumptions 1, 2, and 4 hold, LMIs (45) and (46) admit some feasible solutions. Then, the consensus tracking problem defined in Definition 1 for the multiagent system modeled by ( 1) and ( 4) with switching directed topology can be solved by the neuro-adaptive protocol (6) associated with the observer (8) with control parameters designed by Algorithm 2 if the switching periodic h satisfies the following condition: h > (lnμ)/c 0 , where μ = max i,j ξ j i /min i,j ξ j i , ξ j i , i = 1, 2, . . . , N, j = 1, 2, . . . , q, are defined in (41). Specially, for each i = 1, 2, . . . , N
div.formula: lim t→∞ x i (t) -y(t) ≤(48)
div.p: where
div.formula: = V2 (0)/ ϒ min + ( ν ϒ max )/( d ϒ min ), ϒ min = min i=1,2,...,N {λ min (Q), -1 W i }, ϒ max = max i=1,2,...,N {λ max (Q), -1 W i }, ν = (2κ 0 Q 2 , 2c 1 W M ), κ 0 = M + ω M , and d = min{c 2 λ min (Q), 2c 1 }.
div.p: Proof: Choose the following multiple Lyapunov functions for the switched observer error systems (43): T σ (t) ⊗ P e(t) (49) where σ (t) is defined in (41), P > 0 is given in (45).
div.formula: V1 (t) = e(t)
div.p: Noticing the fact the communication topology G σ (t) is fixed for t ∈ [t k , t k+1 ), for any given k ∈ N, and considering (43), one gets

For an arbitrarily given t > t 2 , there exists a positive integer p ≥ 2 such that t p < t ≤ t p+1 . When t ∈ (t p , t p+1 ), based on the above analysis, one gets
For the case of t = t p+1 , one has
According to (54) and (55), one may conclude that e(t) converges to zero with an exponential decay rate. Construct the following Lyapunov function for the consensus tracking error system (44):
div.formula: V2 (t) = δ(t) T (I N ⊗ Q)δ(t) + tr WT (t) -1 W W(t) (57
div.p: where Q is defined in (47). Using some similar analysis as those employed in the proof of Theorem 1, one may get that
where
div.formula: = V2 (0)/ ϒ min + ( ν ϒ max )/( d ϒ min ), ϒ min = min i=1,2,...,N {λ min (Q), -1 W i }, ϒ max = max i=1,2,...,N {λ max (Q), -1 W i }, ν = (2κ 0 Q 2 , 2c 1 W M ), κ 0 = M + ω M , and d = min{c 2 λ min (Q), 2c 1 }.
div.p: Combining (55), (56), and (58) gives that lim t→∞ x i (t)y(t) ≤ . The proof is thus completed.

Remark 6: To achieve consensus tracking in multiagent system (4) with a high-dimensional leader (1) and directed switching topology, multiple Lyapunov functions have been proposed to prove the exponential stability of the zero equilibrium point of switched systems (43). It can be seen from Theorem 2 that, under some suitable conditions, practical consensus tracking may be ensured if the switching period h is larger than a threshold value. It should be noted that consensus tracking in multiagent system (4) with a high-dimensional leader (1) and directed switching topology can be achieved for an arbitrarily given positive switching period h if there exists a common Lyapunov function for the switched systems (43). However, it is still a challenging yet unsolved problem to find a common Lyapunov for switched systems (43). Furthermore, it is assumed in this paper that the communication channels among neighboring agents work perfectly and the actuators embedded in agents and network topology switch synchronously. It is interesting yet important to further consider how to ensure consensus tracking for multiagent system in the presence of packet dropouts [45], actuator failure [46], and asynchronous switching [47].

Remark 7: By using some similar manipulations as used in Remark 5, the solvability conditions for LMIs ( 45) and ( 46) can be obtained. Since the observer error system (43) becomes a switched system, a class of multiple Lyapunov functions has been constructed to analyze the convergence property of its zero equilibrium point. It is also worth noting that the results given in Theorem 2 can be directly extended to the case of multiagent systems with aperiodic switching directed topologies by using dwell-time-based analysis approach (see [48]).

Remark 8: It is well known in the literature on NN-based control (see [37]) that the size of the compact set in which the states of the control plant are uniformly bounded is not needed in NN-based controller design. Specifically, it can be seen from Theorems 1 and 2 that the bound of the compact set in (10) is not involved in consensus protocol design. In practical applications, the size of could be assumed to be as large as desired such that states x i (t) stay inside for all t > 0. In this sense, the analytic results given in Theorems 1 and 2 are semi-global. It is also worth noting that the results of this paper will be global in the scenario where (10) and (11) hold for all x i (t) ∈ R m , i = 1, 2, . . . , N.

div.head: IV. NUMERICAL SIMULATIONS
div.p: In this section, two numerical examples are provided to verify the effectiveness of the analytical results.

In simulations, the leader is assumed to be the two-massspring system with a single force input [49], whose dynamics can be described by (1) with Furthermore, six neurons are employed for each NN. Sigmoid basis functions are utilized and the NN weight matrices Ŵi (t), i = 1, 2, . . . , 6, are initialized to be zero matrices.
div.formula: = 0 1 0 0 , f i (x i (t)) = (x i1 (t)sin(x i1 t), 2cos(x i2 (t)) T , ω i (t) = (ω i1 (t), ω i2 (t))
div.p: The initial state of the leader is set as θ(0) = (0, 0, 0, 0) T . The evolutions of observer errors e i (t) are provided in Fig. 2 which indicates that the states of observers converge to those of the leader asymptotically. For notational brevity, let δ c i (t) = (δ c i1 , δ c i2 ) T = x i (t)y(t) and u i (t) = (u i1 (t), u i2 (t)) T , for i = 1, 2, . . . , N. Choose c 1 = 0.001 and W i = 2000 for all i = 1, 2, . . . , 6, the profiles of consensus tracking errors δ c i1 (t) and δ c i2 (t) are shown in Figs. 3 and4, respectively. The control inputs u i1 (t) and u i2 (t) are, respectively, provided in Figs. 5 and6. These simulation results verify the effectiveness of analytical results in Theorem 1.

Example 2 (Consensus Over Directed Switching Multiagent Network): Consider multiagent system with a leader given in (1) and followers given in (4), where the topology G σ (t) switches between G 1 and G 2 every 0.9 s with G σ (t) = G 1 for t ∈ [0, 0.9)s. Topologies G 1 and G 2 are shown in Fig. 7, where the communication weights are indicated on edges. By (42), In simulations, four neurons are employed for each NN. Sigmoid basis functions are adopted. The NN weight matrices Ŵi (t), i = 1, 2, 3, 4, are initialized as zero matrices. The initial state of the leader is set as θ(0) = (0, 0, 0, 0) T . Some calculations give that ln(μ) = 1.5547. Choose c1 = 0.001 and W i = 1000, for all i = 1, 2, 3, 4, it can be thus obtained from Theorem 2 that consensus tracking in the closed-loop multiagent system under the protocol designed by Algorithm 2 can be ensured. The evolutions of observer errors e i (t) are provided in Fig. 8 which indicates that the states of observers asymptotically converge to those of the leader. Define δ c i1 (t), δ c i2 (t), u i1 (t), and u i2 (t) the same as those in Example 1. The profiles of consensus tracking errors δ c i1 (t) and δ c i2 (t) are shown in Figs. 9 and 10, respectively. The control inputs u i1 (t) and u i2 (t) are, respectively, provided in Figs. 11 and12. These simulation results demonstrate the effectiveness of the theoretical results in Theorem 2.

V. CONCLUSION By using neuro-adaptive control approach, distributed consensus tracking problem for a class of multiagent systems with unmodeled dynamics and unknown disturbances has been addressed in this paper. In the considered system model, the dimensions of the leader are higher those of the leaders and only some partial state information of the leaders are available to a small group of followers. A distributed full order observer is developed to estimate the unmeasurable state information of the leader. To make the states of followers track the output of leader with bounded residual errors, a local controller based on the designed full-order observer is then proposed for each follower. Theoretical results on consensus tracking with both fixed and switching directed topologies have been derived and analyzed. Future works include the study on consensus tracking of multiple uncertain multiagent systems in the presence of multiple high-dimensional leaders.

div.head: ACKNOWLEDGMENT
div.p: G. Wen would like to acknowledge Prof. H. Zhang for his valuable suggestions on numerical simulations. The authors would like to thank the Associate Editor and the anonymous reviewers for their constructive comments and useful suggestions, which have led to the improvements of the quality of this paper.

This work was supported in part by the National Nature Science Foundation of China under Grant 61304168, Grant 61573096, Grant 61322302, and Grant 61473005, in part by the Natural Science Foundation of Jiangsu Province of China under Grant BK20130595, in part by the National Ten Thousand Talent Program for Young Top-Notch Talents, in part by the Research Fund for the Doctoral Program of Higher Education of China under Grant 20130092120030, in part by the Fundamental Research Funds for the Central Universities of China under Grant 2242016K41030 and Grant 2242016K41058, in part by the Six Talent Peaks of Jiangsu Province under Grant 2014-DZXX-004, and in part by the Australian Research Council Discovery Scheme under Grant DP140100544. This paper was recommended by Associate Editor X.-M. Sun. S'11-M'13) received the Ph.D. degree in mechanical systems and control from Peking University, Beijing, China, in 2012. From 2012 to 2013, he was a Research Associate and a Post-Doctoral Fellow with the University of New South Wales at Canberra, Campbell, ACT, Australia. In 2014, he was a Visiting Research Fellow with the School of Electrical and Computer Engineering, an Associate Dean with the Department of Mathematics, and a Full Professor with the Distinguished Young Honor, Southeast University. He held several visiting positions in Australia, China, Germany, Italy, The Netherlands, and the USA. His current research interests include multiagent systems, complex networks and systems, nonlinear dynamics and control, smart grids, neural networks, game theory, robotics, and optimization. Dr. Yu was a recipient of the Highly Cited Researcher Award in Engineering from Thomson Reuters in 2014 and 2015, respectively, the National Natural Science Fund for Excellent Young Scholars in 2013, the Six Talent Peaks of Jiangsu Province of China in 2014, and the National Ten Thousand Talent Program for Young Top-Notch Talents in 2015.
